metadata.description: Crop-zone suitability factors for 5 optimal crops in Nigeria
metadata.selection_criteria: Maximum regional pattern strength (9.5/10 average score)

Millet.rationale: Extreme North pattern (15× North>South). Sahel staple crop, dies in high humidity due to fungal diseases. Optimal in dry savannas (NW/NE), marginal in Guinea savanna (NC), virtually absent in South.

Sorghum.rationale: Strong North pattern (10× North>South). Slightly more moisture-tolerant than millet but still a drought crop. Thrives in Sudan/Sahel savanna (NE highest), moderate in Guinea savanna (NC), minimal in humid South.

Groundnuts.rationale: Strong North pattern (8× North>South). Famous 'groundnut pyramid' documented in Kano (NW). Waterlogging kills crop, requires well-drained sandy soils. Best in dry savanna with distinct dry season.

Oil palm fruit.rationale: Extreme South pattern (infinite - ONLY South). Oil palm belt documented in SE/SS. Requires year-round rainfall (>1500mm) and high humidity. Cannot survive Harmattan dry season. Zero production in North, optimal in rainforest zones.

Cocoa beans.rationale: Extreme South-West pattern (20× SW>North). Famous cocoa belt in SW (Ondo, Ekiti, Oyo states). Requires rainforest/derived savanna conditions, shade, high humidity. SW is optimal with long cocoa farming tradition.

historical_evidence.Oil palm fruit: Oil palm belt (Rivers, Akwa Ibom, Cross River states)
historical_evidence.Cocoa beans: Cocoa belt (Ondo, Ekiti, Oyo, Ogun states)
historical_evidence.Sorghum: Sudan savanna staple (Borno, Yobe, Gombe states)

biophysical_constraints.Millet: Dies in humidity (fungal diseases), requires <600mm rainfall
biophysical_constraints.Sorghum: Drought-tolerant, survives 400-800mm rainfall, sensitive to waterlogging
biophysical_constraints.Groundnuts: Waterlogging kills crop, requires sandy well-drained soil
biophysical_constraints.Oil palm fruit: Requires >1500mm rainfall, dies in dry season
biophysical_constraints.Cocoa beans: Requires rainforest shade, dies in Harmattan
